awd_titl_txt: Amphiphilic Siderophores: Biosynthesis, Iron Uptake and Effect on Microbial Growth
awd_abstract_narration:
Nearly all bacteria require iron to grow.  Understanding the process by which bacteria obtain iron from their surroundings provides valuable insight into how to disrupt the iron uptake process, and suggests potential new strategies to limit growth of deleterious microbes.  The focus of this proposal is to find out how unique compounds called siderophores are produced for iron uptake in Vibrio harveyi and other microbes for which their production is tied to bacterial colony formation and survival.  Siderophores are natural materials produced by bacteria that bind iron(III) very tightly playing a vital role in iron uptake by the bacterium. Through these investigations, graduate students will be trained in the application of a broad spectrum of modern techniques to a multidisciplinary research program.  The graduate students will, in turn, also gain valuable experience as mentors to undergraduate researchers in the laboratory, and undergraduates will gain hands-on research experience.

With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Alison Butler from the University of California, Santa Barbara to investigate the biosynthesis of key amphiphilic siderophores, such as the amphi-enterobactins, to investigate their physical properties including the ferric stability constants and membrane partitioning constants for different forms of the amphi-enterobactins, to investigate key esterases and outer membrane receptor proteins present in the genome of V. harveyi which are suspected to be important in the mechanism of iron uptake, as well as to investigate other key amphiphilic siderophores.  V. harveyi is the widely studied model organism for quorum sensing, the process by which bacteria sense cell density.  Discoveries from these investigations will provide new insights into the importance of the fatty acid in acylated siderophores in the iron uptake process.

por.por_cntn:
Bacteria require iron to grow, and many produce siderophores to facilitate iron uptake. Siderophores are low MW chelating ligands that coordinate Fe(III) with very high affinity. A newly recognized distinguishing characteristic of siderophores produced by marine bacteria is the prevalence of suites of amphiphilic siderophores, one family of which is based on a common Fe(III)-coordinating head group and appended by one of a series of fatty acid tails. 

In terms of the intellectual merit of this research, the goals of this project were to investigate the biosynthetic pathways of acylated siderophores and the subsequent tailoring processes that hydrolyze the fatty acid.  Using genomic predictions, we identified new biosynthetic gene clusters for amphiphilic siderophores and then isolated and characterized these siderophores. We carried out investigations of amphi-enterobactin siderophores from Vibrio harveyi BAA1116, amphibactin siderophores from many Vibrio species and Alcanivorax borkumensis SK2, as well as marinobactin siderophores from Marinobacter nanhaiticus D15-8 W and Marinobacter sp. DS40M6. Based on the catechol and Lys content of the expanded enterobactin-like siderophore, cyclic tri-chrysobactin (CTC), which resembles the adhesive mussel foot proteins in terms of the catechol to cationic amino acid ratio, we investigated the aqueous adhesive properties of CTC and related analogs. We found that the presence of both the cationic amino acid (Lys, diamino butyric acid) and the catechol is essential for adhesion of these compounds to mica in aqueous solution.

For broader impacts within the scientific community, we have shown that acylated siderophores are widely present in terrestrial bacteria, in addition to marine bacteria, and that robust wet adhesion is achieved by catechol-amine compounds resembling the adhesive mussel foot proteins. For impact in training and outreach, the current grant period provided multidisciplinary training to the graduate students and undergraduates in my laboratory, and international exposure through extended visits of two graduate students, one from Taiwan, and one from, as well as the visit of a Professor from Spain. Ten graduate students, and five undergraduates carried out research on this project. During this grant period, three students obtained their PhD degrees, and received his MS degree. One graduate student co-led the UCSB Institute for Scientist and Engineer Educators (ISEE) outreach program, preparing early career scientists for higher education teaching roles.  I also served a term on the External Advisory Committee of the NSF/NIH Minority Opportunities in Research (MORE) Program at California State University, Los Angeles.  In March of 2016, I was the MARC (Minority Access to Research Careers) Scholars Lecturer at California State University Fullerton, and I spent the day and evening interacting with the students on their projects.  One of these students was accepted to the UCSB graduate program and has joined my research group.
